title.narrative: UNESCWA- Small-Scale Ren Energy in rural and urban areas in MENA (REGEND)

description.narrative: REGEND is a regional initiative to promote small-scale renewable energy applications in rural areas of the Arab region. REGEND works in three countries; Lebanon, Jordan and Tunisia (original design also Morocco but was excluded after dialogue with the country) to support the development of strategic country plans to promote access to sustainable, modern energy services as a means to support rural livelihoods across sectors. Field projects are also being implemented in the three countries. The project addendum is a separate component but builds on the activities of the core project by enhancing regional and local capacity for pursuing water and food security in a changing climate context. The overarching goal of the addendum is to improve access and ability to use regional and localized climate analysis to inform coherent water and agricultural policies and inform climate action for improved water and food security in the Arab region.

UNESCWA has applied for 42 MSEK for implementing a project on Promoting Small-Scale Renewable Energy Applications in rural areas of the Middle East and North Africa region during the period of 2018-2021. The project will be implemented in four countries in the region: Lebanon, Jordan, Tunisia and Morocco.
The intervention is aiming to improve the livelihood, economic benefits, social inclusion and gender equality of Arab rural communities particularly marginalised groups, by addressing energy poverty, water scarcity and vulnerability to climate change and other natural resources challenges. This will be pursued through using appropriate small-scale renewable energy technologies for productive activities and entrepreneurial development.
The intervention's total budget is 46 MSEK out of which UNESCWAs own funding is approximately 4 MSEK and the remaining 42 MSEK is applied for from Sida.
UNESCWA is the lead implementing party of this project and Sida's agreement partner. However, they will work with other partner organisations to support the implementation of the pilot projects and other activities of the Projects. Funds will be forwarded only to: Office Nationale de l'Electricité et de l'Eau Potable (ONEE), the Royal Scientific Society (RSS), the Lebanese Center for Energy Conservation (LCEC), the Maroccan Agency for Solar Energy. Further collaboration (not involving forwarding of fund) and work on synergies will take place with the League of Arab States (LAS), the Arab Industrial Development and Mining Organization (AIDMO), Local and Regional NGOs, UNHCR and other relevant actors.

United Nations Economic and Social Commission, UNESCWA, har ansökt om 42 miljoner kronor för att genomföra ett projekt i syfte att främja användningen av småskalig förnybar energi i landsbygdsområdena i Mellanöstern och Nordafrika, MENA, under perioden 2018-2021. Projektet kommer att implementeras i fyra länder i regionen: Libanon, Jordanien, Tunisien och Marocko.
Insatsen syftar till att förbättra försörjningsmöjligheter, ge ekonomiska fördelar, stödja social integration och jämställdhet inom samhällen på landsbygden i regionen med särskilt fokus på marginaliserade grupper. Stödet syftar till att ta itu med energifattigdom, vattenbrist och sårbarhet för klimatförändringar och andra utmaningar länkade till naturresurser.
Projektet kommer att drivas genom att skapa en mekanism som främjar användandet av tillämplig småskalig förnybar energiteknik för produktiv verksamhet samt entreprenörsutveckling inom förnyelsebar energi. Interventionens totala budget är 46 MSEK varav UNESCWA finansierar cirka 4 MSEK och resterande 42 MSEK har sökts från Sida.
UNESCWA kommer leda implementeringen av projektet och vara Sidas avtalspartner. UNESCWA kommer dock att samarbeta med ett antal partnerorganisationer i genomförandet av pilotprojekten och övriga aktiviteter. Detta kommer innebära vidareförmedling från UNESCWA till Office Nationale de l'Electricité et de l'Eau Potable (ONEE), Royal Scientific Society (RSS), Lebanese Center for Energy Conservation (LCEC), the Moroccan Agency for Solar Energy. Samarbete kommer även att ske (utan vidareförmedling) med League of Arab States (LAS), Arab Industrial Development and Mining Organization (AIDMO), lokala och regionala civilsamhällesorganisationer, UNHCR och andra relevanta aktörer. De första sex månaderna kommer att utgöra en inceptionsfas då UNESCWA tillsammans med implementerande parter utarbetar detaljerna för den kommande implementeringen av projektet.

participating-org.narrative: Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia

sector.narrative: Energy generation, renewable sources - multiple technologies

tag.narrative: 13.2 - Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.
13.2 - Integrera klimatåtgärder i politik, strategier och planering på nationell nivå.

7.b - By 2030, expand infrastructure and upgrade technology for supplying modern and sustainable energy services for all in developing countries, in particular least developed countries, small island developing States and landlocked developing countries, in accordance with their respective programmes of support.

7.b - Till 2030 bygga ut infrastrukturen och uppgradera tekniken för att leverera moderna och hållbara energitjänster till alla i utvecklingsländerna, i synnerhet de minst utvecklade länderna och små önationer under utveckling.

description.narrative: REGEND - Despite the movement and travel restrictions imposed due to COVID-19, which came into effect starting in March 2020, REGEND continued its activities and the team organized a number of meetings, workshops, and events digitally. - REGEND was able to generate knowledge products that were used for national and regional consultation and training workshops, both at policy and technical levels and were disseminated to key stakeholders and through a REGEND-dedicated webpage. - The partnership with the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources in Jordan (MEMR) enabled them to participate in and lead some training sessions within the scope of the capacity building workshops organized and they were able to assist some of the trainees and local community members in resolving issues they were having with the electricity grid connection and local electrical distribution company. This resulted in a positive impact which reduced the communication and interaction gap between the ministry and the local rural population, and which has is considered a noteworthy added value facilitated by REGEND’s integrated, participative, and hands-on approach. The project addendum - Despite the postponement of COP26 from Nov 2019 to 2021, the project was able to secure consensus among Arab States on the need to engage in the Koronivia Joint Work on Agriculture (KJWA) process and to provide national and joint regional submissions to the Subsidiary Body for Scientific and Technological Advice (SBSTA) and the Subsidiary Body for Implementation (SBI) of the UNFCCC, in addition to agreeing to working on achieving a harmonized Arab position and to taking measures to adapt the key agriculture sector to climate change. - The project was also able to integrate the emerging impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on food and water security in the Arab region through the preparation of policy briefs and holding virtual dialogues to take stock of actions on the ground. - Based on discussions with Sida, SMHI, ACSAD and project counterparts, a new Mashreq Domain was set up to frame the set of regional climate modelling projections being pursued under the project addendum. The domain was expanded to extend from the headwaters of the Tigris and Euphrates rivers to Yemen and neighbouring areas. Two projections out of six have already been generated and work on the bias correction methodology has been initiated within the framework of the MoU signed with SMHI.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
